elements.content: A new supermolecular building blocks (SBBs) based microporous metal–organic framework (MOF) was prepared with both 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc) and 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) as ligands. The obtained CoII MOF reveals an uncommon ftw-a-like structure from the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs under the direction of tpt and exhibits selective gas adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter and temperature which might have application in gas separation purposes.
elements.clean_text: A new supermolecular building blocks (SBBs) based microporous metal-organic framework (MOF) was prepared with both 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc) and 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) as ligands. The obtained CoII MOF reveals an uncommon ftw-a-like structure from the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs under the direction of tpt and exhibits selective gas adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter and temperature which might have application in gas separation purposes.

elements.content: A new supermolecular building blocks (SBBs) based microporous metal−organic framework (MOF) was prepared with both 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc) and 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) as ligands. The obtained CoII MOF reveals an uncommon ftw-a-like structure from the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs under the direction of tpt and exhibits selective gas adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter at 77 K.
elements.clean_text: A new supermolecular building blocks (SBBs) based microporous metal-organic framework (MOF) was prepared with both 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc) and 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) as ligands. The obtained CoII MOF reveals an uncommon ftw-a-like structure from the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs under the direction of tpt and exhibits selective gas adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter at 77 K.

elements.content: Porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted great attention in the past two decades because of their captivating structural diversities and potential applications, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and chemical sensing. Therefore, much effort has been focused on the design and controlled synthesis of porous MOFs. Among the methods reported, the molecular building block (MBB) approach has recently emerged as a powerful strategy to design and construct porous MOFs for its potential toward prediction, design, and synthesis of the resultant framework. The network topologies as well as pore size and surface characteristics can be easily tailored by the assembly of supermolecular building blocks (SBBs) constructed with rigid angular polycarboxylate ligands (e.g., 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H3btc) with in situ formed secondary building units (SBUs).
elements.clean_text: Porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted great attention in the past two decades because of their captivating structural diversities and potential applications, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and chemical sensing. Therefore, much effort has been focused on the design and controlled synthesis of porous MOFs. Among the methods reported, the molecular building block (MBB) approach has recently emerged as a powerful strategy to design and construct porous MOFs for its potential toward prediction, design, and synthesis of the resultant framework. The network topologies as well as pore size and surface characteristics can be easily tailored by the assembly of supermolecular building blocks (SBBs) constructed with rigid angular polycarboxylate ligands (e.g., 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, H3btc) with in situ formed secondary building units (SBUs).

elements.content: On the other hand, rigid triangular multipyridyl ligand 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) is of special interest in recent years for its possibility to construct MOFs with interesting high symmetry structures and attractive properties. As the combination of tpt and carboxylate spacers in MOFs constructions has been proved to be a useful method to take advantages of different types of ligands, we expect that the introduction of tpt accompanied by polycarboxylate ligand in SBBs based MOFs constructions could direct the assembly and arrangement of SBUs/SBBs to result in MOFs with novel topologies and properties. Herein, we present the synthesis and structure of a three-dimensional (3D) microporous CoII MOF based on SBBs with both H3btc and tpt as ligands. The MOF obtained reveals an uncommon ftw-a-like topology from the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs constructed with btc3− ligands and CoII ions under the direction of tpt ligands and exhibits selective gas adsorption properties at 77 K.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, rigid triangular multipyridyl ligand 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) is of special interest in recent years for its possibility to construct MOFs with interesting high symmetry structures and attractive properties. As the combination of tpt and carboxylate spacers in MOFs constructions has been proved to be a useful method to take advantages of different types of ligands, we expect that the introduction of tpt accompanied by polycarboxylate ligand in SBBs based MOFs constructions could direct the assembly and arrangement of SBUs/SBBs to result in MOFs with novel topologies and properties. Herein, we present the synthesis and structure of a three-dimensional (3D) microporous CoII MOF based on SBBs with both H3btc and tpt as ligands. The MOF obtained reveals an uncommon ftw-a-like topology from the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs constructed with btc3- ligands and CoII ions under the direction of tpt ligands and exhibits selective gas adsorption properties at 77 K.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2011-00043a_0005.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The solvothermal reaction of Co(NO3)2·6H2O with H3btc and tpt in a mixture of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF)/ethanol/water results in the formation of a red cubic-like crystal of [Co9(btc)6(tpt)2(H2O)15]·solve (1) which was structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallized in trigonal space group R3̅m. In the asymmetric unit, there are three kinds of CoII ions with different coordination environments. Both Co1 and Co2 are six coordinated with similar octahedral geometry. With one μ2-OH2 and two bis-monodentate carboxylates as bridge, Co1 and Co2 are linked to form square SBU (Figure a and ), similar to the reported one in MOF-501 with the terminal water ligand at the axial site of Co2 replaced by one N atom (N3)from the pyridyl of tpt ligand. Co3 is also six coordinated but presents a distorted octahedral geometry. Each Co3 is coordinated by three carboxylates, two with bis-monodentate mode and one with chelating mode, and the coordination sphere is completed with one terminal water molecule and one N atom from the pyridyl of tpt ligand. Two central symmetric related Co3 are bridged by the bis-monodentate carboxylates to form another kind of square SBU (Figure c and ). For the SBUs constructed with Co1 and Co2, six SBUs are bonded together by twelve btc3− ligands to form a cubohemioctahedra SBB with the vertices occupied by btc3− ligands and the SBUs occupying the centers of six square faces (Figure b). Furthermore, the SBBs are interconnected by Co3 contained square SBUs via the isophthalate portion carboxylates left at vertices to form a framework with ftw-a-like topology (Figure d). It has been reported that the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs could result in the fcu-like structures, while the topology we got here is uncommon in MOFs. It should be noted that if btc3– ligands and two kinds of square SBUs were treated as 3-connected and 4-connected nodes, respectively, the present framework can also be interpreted topologically as a novel (3,4,4)-connected ternary net with point (Schlafli) symbol (6·82)4(64·82)2(84·122) (see the ).
elements.clean_text: The solvothermal reaction of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O with H3btc and tpt in a mixture of N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF)/ethanol/water results in the formation of a red cubic-like crystal of [Co9(btc)6(tpt)2(H2O)15]⋅solve (1) which was structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallized in trigonal space group R3̅m. In the asymmetric unit, there are three kinds of CoII ions with different coordination environments. Both Co1 and Co2 are six coordinated with similar octahedral geometry. With one μ2-OH2 and two bis-monodentate carboxylates as bridge, Co1 and Co2 are linked to form square SBU (Figure a and ), similar to the reported one in MOF-501 with the terminal water ligand at the axial site of Co2 replaced by one N atom (N3)from the pyridyl of tpt ligand. Co3 is also six coordinated but presents a distorted octahedral geometry. Each Co3 is coordinated by three carboxylates, two with bis-monodentate mode and one with chelating mode, and the coordination sphere is completed with one terminal water molecule and one N atom from the pyridyl of tpt ligand. Two central symmetric related Co3 are bridged by the bis-monodentate carboxylates to form another kind of square SBU (Figure c and ). For the SBUs constructed with Co1 and Co2, six SBUs are  bonded together by twelve btc3- ligands to form a cubohemioctahedra SBB with the vertices occupied by btc3- ligands and the SBUs occupying the centers of six square faces (Figure b). Furthermore, the SBBs are interconnected by Co3 contained square SBUs via the isophthalate portion carboxylates left at vertices to form a framework with ftw-a-like topology (Figure d). It has been reported that the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs could result in the fcu-like structures, while the topology we got here is uncommon in MOFs. It should be noted that if btc3- ligands and two kinds of square SBUs were treated as 3-connected and 4-connected nodes, respectively, the present framework can also be interpreted topologically as a novel (3,4,4)-connected ternary net with point (Schlafli) symbol (6⋅82)4(64⋅82)2(84⋅122) (see the ).

elements.content: (a) Square shaped SBU constructed with Co1 and Co2. (b) Cubohemioctahedra supermolecular building block (SBB) from the assembly of square SBUs. (c) Square SBU constructed with Co3. (d) Scheme view of the ftw-a-like topology from the assembly of SBBs. Part of the coordinated water molecules and the N atoms from tpt ligands were omitted.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Square shaped SBU constructed with Co1 and Co2. (b) Cubohemioctahedra supermolecular building block (SBB) from the assembly of square SBUs. (c) Square SBU constructed with Co3. (d) Scheme view of the  ftw-a-like topology from the assembly of SBBs. Part of the coordinated water molecules and the N atoms from tpt ligands were omitted.

elements.content: Compared with the reported MOFs constructed by cubohemioctahedra SBBs, the terminal water ligands at the axial site of SBU were replaced by N atoms from rigid trigonal tpt ligands; then the assembly and arrangement of SBBs was directed by the conformation of tpt ligands as well as that of btc3– ligands. Tpt ligands presented in the framework could be divided into two classes according to their different connections (Figure ). For tpt ligands coordinated to Co2 only, three cubohemioctahedra SBBs are joined by one tpt ligand through their square face centers, and each cubohemioctahedra SBB was extended by six tpt ligands to show layer arrangement along the ab plane. The other class of tpt ligand joins only Co3 contained SBUs together to result in honeycomb-like layers along the ab plane (see the ). Furthermore, controls were performed to confirm the role of tpt ligand in the formation of the MOF. When experiments were carried out with the tpt ligand excluded or replaced by the same amount of pyridine, only two-dimensional (2D) layer structures could be obtained. Then it could be concluded that though the backbone of the highly symmetrical framework is mainly defined by the assembly of SBBs constructed with Co-SBUs and btc3– ligands, the resultant structure is also determined by the multipyridyl ligand tpt which has an effect on the formation of Co-SBUs as well as the assembly and arrangement of SBBs.
elements.clean_text: Compared with the reported MOFs constructed by cubohemioctahedra SBBs, the terminal water ligands at the axial site of SBU were replaced by N atoms from rigid trigonal tpt ligands; then the assembly and arrangement of SBBs was directed by the conformation of tpt ligands as well as that of btc3- ligands. Tpt ligands presented in the framework could be divided into two classes according to their different connections (Figure ). For tpt ligands coordinated to Co2 only, three cubohemioctahedra SBBs are joined by one tpt ligand through their square face centers, and each cubohemioctahedra SBB was extended by six tpt ligands to show layer arrangement along the ab plane. The other class of tpt ligand joins only Co3 contained SBUs together to result in honeycomb-like layers along the ab plane (see the ). Furthermore, controls were performed to confirm the role of tpt ligand in the formation of the MOF. When experiments were carried out with the tpt ligand excluded or replaced by the same amount of pyridine, only two-dimensional (2D) layer structures could be obtained. Then it could be concluded that though the backbone of the highly symmetrical framework is mainly defined by the assembly of SBBs constructed with Co-SBUs and btc3- ligands, the resultant structure is also determined by the multipyridyl ligand tpt which has an effect on the formation of Co-SBUs as well as the assembly and arrangement of SBBs.

elements.content: Two classes of tpt ligand depending on different connections.
elements.clean_text: 2  Two classes of tpt ligand depending on different connections.

elements.content: Owing to the assembly of SBBs, the overall framework of 1 consists of two types of open cages (Figure ). The larger type, having an ca. 8 Å diameter, is delimited by two parallel tpt ligands, and the accordingly connected Co3 contained MBBs. One large cage is surrounded by eight cubohemioctahedra small cages which have a dimension of ca. 6 Å including the coordinated water molecules. These two types of cages are interconnected via small triangle windows to give into a 3D pore system. The total solvent-accessible volume for 1 was estimated to be 49% by summing voxels more than 1.2 Å away from the framework using PLATON software.
elements.clean_text: Owing to the assembly of SBBs, the overall framework of 1 consists of two types of open cages (Figure ). The larger type, having an ca. 8 Å diameter, is delimited by two parallel tpt ligands, and the accordingly connected Co3 contained MBBs. One large cage is surrounded by eight cubohemioctahedra small cages which have a dimension of ca. 6 Å including the coordinated water molecules. These two types of cages are interconnected via small triangle windows to give into a 3D pore system. The total solvent-accessible volume for 1 was estimated to be 49% by summing voxels more than 1.2 Å away from the framework using PLATON software.

elements.content: Open cages in the framework interconnected with triangle windows. The yellow and violet spheres represent the inner space of cages with 8 Å and 6 Å diameters separately.
elements.clean_text: 3  Open cages in the framework interconnected with triangle windows. The yellow and violet spheres represent the inner space of cages with 8 Å and 6 Å diameters separately.

elements.content: In order to assess the porosity of 1, gas sorption measurements were carried out. Fresh sample of 1 was first solvent exchanged with ethanol and then outgassed at room temperature. However, the activated sample adsorbs no N2 at 77 K but reveals a moderate absorption of H2 (100.3 cm3 g–1 STP, 0.89 wt % at 900 mmHg) (Figure a). The activated sample adsorbs CO2 gas up to 16.8 wt % (78.02 cm3 g–1 STP) at 195 K and 1 atm. Though the activated sample has a broadened PXRD pattern (Figure S2 of the ), the typical type-I behavior of the CO2 adsorption isotherm confirmed the microporous characteristic of this material (Figure b). It has been reported that some MOFs having broad PXRD patterns also adsorb gases to show permanent porosity. However, the gas uptakes are not as high as the pore volume derived from the crystal structure. This suggests that the framework of 1 is significantly collapsed or shrunk by the removal of the guests. Then the selective sorption of gases could be attributed to the small apertures of cages that prevent the entrance of N2 (kinetic diameter: 3.64 Å) but allow the diffusion of H2 (kinetic diameter: 2.89 Å) and CO2 (kinetic diameter: 3.30 Å) into the cages. In addition, the significant quadrupole moment of CO2 (−1.4 × 10–39 C m2) might induce a stronger interaction with the host framework. The small apertures also result in the hysteresis in H2 adsorption/desorption by increasing the synergistic effect of the neighboring pore walls and accordingly slow the adsorption kinetics. To further investigate the hydrogen capacity of 1, the isosteric heat of sorption was calculated from the hydrogen adsorption data collected at 77 and 87 K (Figure a). At the lowest coverage, the Q st reaches 8.1 kJ/mol (Figure S5 of the ). This value is comparable with that of many previous MOFs. Also, the isosteric heat of hydrogen shows little loading dependence, which is in accordance with the fact that the narrow apertures could induce stronger interaction between the gas molecule and the host framework. The selective adsorption of 1 for H2 over N2 at 77 K is comparable with many reported MOFs. This makes it a good candidate for the gas separation processes in H2 enrichment from N2–H2 exhaust mixtures resulting from ammonia synthesis.
elements.clean_text: In order to assess the porosity of 1, gas sorption measurements were carried out. Fresh sample of 1 was first solvent exchanged with ethanol and then outgassed at room temperature. However, the activated sample adsorbs no N2 at 77 K but reveals a moderate absorption of H2 (100.3 cm3 g-1 STP, 0.89 wt % at 900 mmHg) (Figure a). The activated sample adsorbs CO2 gas up to 16.8 wt % (78.02 cm3 g-1 STP) at 195 K and 1 atm. Though the activated sample has a broadened PXRD pattern (Figure S2 of the ), the typical type-I behavior of the CO2 adsorption isotherm confirmed the microporous characteristic of this material (Figure b). It has been reported that some MOFs having broad PXRD patterns also adsorb gases to show permanent porosity. However, the gas uptakes are not as high as the pore volume derived from the crystal structure. This suggests that the framework of 1 is significantly collapsed or shrunk by the removal of the guests. Then the selective sorption of gases could be attributed to the small apertures of cages that prevent the entrance of N2 (kinetic diameter: 3.64 Å) but allow the diffusion of H2 (kinetic diameter: 2.89 Å) and CO2 (kinetic diameter: 3.30 Å) into the cages. In addition, the significant quadrupole moment of CO2 (-1.4 × 10-39 C m2) might induce a stronger interaction with the host framework. The small apertures also result in the hysteresis in H2 adsorption/desorption by increasing the synergistic effect of the neighboring pore walls and accordingly slow the adsorption kinetics. To further investigate the hydrogen capacity of 1, the isosteric heat of sorption was calculated from the hydrogen adsorption data collected at 77 and 87 K (Figure a). At the lowest coverage, the Q st reaches 8.1 kJ/mol (Figure S5 of the ). This value is comparable with that of many previous MOFs. Also, the isosteric heat of hydrogen shows little loading dependence, which is in accordance with the fact that the narrow apertures could induce stronger interaction between the gas molecule and the host framework. The selective adsorption of 1 for H2 over N2 at 77 K is comparable with many reported MOFs. This makes it a good candidate for the gas separation processes in H2 enrichment from N2-H2 exhaust mixtures resulting from ammonia synthesis.

elements.content: Gas sorption isotherms of the activated 1. Adsorption and desorption data are shown as filled and open symbols, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 4  Gas sorption isotherms of the activated 1. Adsorption and desorption data are shown as filled and open symbols, respectively.

elements.content: Furthermore, we investigated the material’s separation capability between CO2 and CH4, which might be used in the elimination of contaminant carbon dioxide from natural gas and landfill gas streams. Based on the selectivity of H2 over N2, we expected that the selectivity of CO2 over CH4 should be high, owing to the significant differences between gas molecule diameters (CO2 3.30 Å and CH4 3.758 Å) and the molecular sieving effect of the narrow apertures. Indeed, as the experiment reveals, 1 adsorbs 10.6 wt % (54.3 cm3 g–1 STP) CO2 at 273 K and 900 mmHg. However, it could adsorb 1.7 wt % (23.5 cm3 g–1 STP) CH4 under the same condition (Figure b). The permission of CH4 into the cages might be due to the increased gas molecule diffusivity at 273 K. At this temperature, both CO2 and CH4 molecules have sufficient kinetic energy to diffuse within the cages freely. As a result, no hysteresis is observed for both gases. Comparing the adsorption behaviors of 1 at different temperatures, it could be concluded that 1 demonstrates selective adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter at 77 K, which might have application in gas separation purposes.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, we investigated the material's separation capability between CO2 and CH4, which might be used in the elimination of contaminant carbon dioxide from natural gas and landfill gas streams. Based on the selectivity of H2 over N2, we expected that the selectivity of CO2 over CH4 should be high, owing to the significant differences between gas molecule diameters (CO2 3.30 Å and CH4 3.758 Å) and the molecular sieving effect of the narrow apertures. Indeed, as the experiment reveals, 1 adsorbs 10.6 wt % (54.3 cm3 g-1 STP) CO2 at 273 K and 900 mmHg. However, it could adsorb 1.7 wt % (23.5 cm3 g-1 STP) CH4 under the same condition (Figure b). The permission of CH4 into the cages might be due to the increased gas molecule diffusivity at 273 K. At this temperature, both CO2 and CH4 molecules have sufficient kinetic energy to diffuse within the cages freely. As a result, no hysteresis is observed for both gases. Comparing the adsorption behaviors of 1 at different temperatures, it could be concluded that 1 demonstrates selective adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter at 77 K, which might have application in gas separation purposes.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully prepared a 3D microporous MOF based on SBBs with tpt and H3btc as ligands. The CoII MOF obtained reveals an uncommon ftw-a-like topology from the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs composed of Co-SBUs and btc3– ligands, and the tpt ligand presented in the framework plays an important role in the assembly process to determine the final structure. Also, the 3D pore system in the material contains cages with small interconnecting apertures. The activated material reveals selective adsorption of gases depending on their molecule diameter at 77 K. As a result of its novel structure and unusual sorption behavior, the MOF reported here may serve as a prototype for the construction of new SBBs based MOFs.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully prepared a 3D microporous MOF based on SBBs with tpt and H3btc as ligands. The CoII MOF obtained reveals an uncommon ftw-a-like topology from the assembly of cubohemioctahedra SBBs composed of Co-SBUs and btc3- ligands, and the tpt ligand presented in the framework plays an important role in the assembly process to determine the final structure. Also, the 3D pore system in the material contains cages with small interconnecting apertures. The activated material reveals selective adsorption of gases depending on their molecule diameter at 77 K. As a result of its novel structure and unusual sorption behavior, the MOF reported here may serve as a prototype for the construction of new SBBs based MOFs.

elements.content: Crystal data for 1: C30H14Co3N4O17, M r = 879.24, trigonal, R3̅m, a = b = 27.422(3) Å, c = 38.087(8) Å, V = 24803(6) Å3, Z = 18, d calcd = 1.060 g·cm–3, reflections collected/unique/ observed: 60253/5791/4726, R int = 0.084, final R 1 = 0.0677 (I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.1938 (all data), GOF = 1.08.
elements.clean_text:
References

Crystal data for 1: C30H14Co3N4O17, M r = 879.24, trigonal, R3̅m, a = b = 27.422(3) Å, c = 38.087(8) Å, V = 24803(6) Å3, Z = 18, d calcd = 1.060 g⋅cm-3, reflections collected/unique/ observed: 60253/5791/4726, R int = 0.084, final R 1 = 0.0677 (I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.1938 (all data), GOF = 1.08.

cln_elements.content:
Owing to the assembly of SBBs, the overall framework of 1 consists of two types of open cages (Figure ). The larger type, having an ca. 8 Å diameter, is delimited by two parallel tpt ligands, and the accordingly connected Co3 contained MBBs. One large cage is surrounded by eight cubohemioctahedra small cages which have a dimension of ca. 6 Å including the coordinated water molecules. These two types of cages are interconnected via small triangle windows to give into a 3D pore system. The total solvent-accessible volume for 1 was estimated to be 49% by summing voxels more than 1.2 Å away from the framework using PLATON software.

In order to assess the porosity of 1, gas sorption measurements were carried out. Fresh sample of 1 was first solvent exchanged with ethanol and then outgassed at room temperature. However, the activated sample adsorbs no N2 at 77 K but reveals a moderate absorption of H2 (100.3 cm3 g–1 STP, 0.89 wt % at 900 mmHg) (Figure a). The activated sample adsorbs CO2 gas up to 16.8 wt % (78.02 cm3 g–1 STP) at 195 K and 1 atm. Though the activated sample has a broadened PXRD pattern (Figure S2 of the ), the typical type-I behavior of the CO2 adsorption isotherm confirmed the microporous characteristic of this material (Figure b). It has been reported that some MOFs having broad PXRD patterns also adsorb gases to show permanent porosity. However, the gas uptakes are not as high as the pore volume derived from the crystal structure. This suggests that the framework of 1 is significantly collapsed or shrunk by the removal of the guests. Then the selective sorption of gases could be attributed to the small apertures of cages that prevent the entrance of N2 (kinetic diameter: 3.64 Å) but allow the diffusion of H2 (kinetic diameter: 2.89 Å) and CO2 (kinetic diameter: 3.30 Å) into the cages. In addition, the significant quadrupole moment of CO2 (−1.4 × 10–39 C m2) might induce a stronger interaction with the host framework. The small apertures also result in the hysteresis in H2 adsorption/desorption by increasing the synergistic effect of the neighboring pore walls and accordingly slow the adsorption kinetics. To further investigate the hydrogen capacity of 1, the isosteric heat of sorption was calculated from the hydrogen adsorption data collected at 77 and 87 K (Figure a). At the lowest coverage, the Q st reaches 8.1 kJ/mol (Figure S5 of the ). This value is comparable with that of many previous MOFs. Also, the isosteric heat of hydrogen shows little loading dependence, which is in accordance with the fact that the narrow apertures could induce stronger interaction between the gas molecule and the host framework. The selective adsorption of 1 for H2 over N2 at 77 K is comparable with many reported MOFs. This makes it a good candidate for the gas separation processes in H2 enrichment from N2–H2 exhaust mixtures resulting from ammonia synthesis.

Furthermore, we investigated the material’s separation capability between CO2 and CH4, which might be used in the elimination of contaminant carbon dioxide from natural gas and landfill gas streams. Based on the selectivity of H2 over N2, we expected that the selectivity of CO2 over CH4 should be high, owing to the significant differences between gas molecule diameters (CO2 3.30 Å and CH4 3.758 Å) and the molecular sieving effect of the narrow apertures. Indeed, as the experiment reveals, 1 adsorbs 10.6 wt % (54.3 cm3 g–1 STP) CO2 at 273 K and 900 mmHg. However, it could adsorb 1.7 wt % (23.5 cm3 g–1 STP) CH4 under the same condition (Figure b). The permission of CH4 into the cages might be due to the increased gas molecule diffusivity at 273 K. At this temperature, both CO2 and CH4 molecules have sufficient kinetic energy to diffuse within the cages freely. As a result, no hysteresis is observed for both gases. Comparing the adsorption behaviors of 1 at different temperatures, it could be concluded that 1 demonstrates selective adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter at 77 K, which might have application in gas separation purposes.

References

Crystal data for 1: C30H14Co3N4O17, M r = 879.24, trigonal, R3̅m, a = b = 27.422(3) Å, c = 38.087(8) Å, V = 24803(6) Å3, Z = 18, d calcd = 1.060 g·cm–3, reflections collected/unique/ observed: 60253/5791/4726, R int = 0.084, final R 1 = 0.0677 (I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.1938 (all data), GOF = 1.08.

One large cage is surrounded by eight cubohemioctahedra small cages which have a dimension of ca. 6 Å including the coordinated water molecules. These two types of cages are interconnected via small triangle windows to give into a 3D pore system. The total solvent-accessible volume for 1 was estimated to be 49% by summing voxels more than 1.2 Å away from the framework using PLATON software.

The activated sample adsorbs CO2 gas up to 16.8 wt % (78.02 cm3 g-1 STP) at 195 K and 1 atm. However, the gas uptakes are not as high as the pore volume derived from the crystal structure. This suggests that the framework of 1 is significantly collapsed or shrunk by the removal of the guests. Then the selective sorption of gases could be attributed to the small apertures of cages that prevent the entrance of N2 (kinetic diameter: 3.64 Å) but allow the diffusion of H2 (kinetic diameter: 2.89 Å) and CO2 (kinetic diameter: 3.30 Å) into the cages. In addition, the significant quadrupole moment of CO2 (-1.4 × 10-39 C m2) might induce a stronger interaction with the host framework. The small apertures also result in the hysteresis in H2 adsorption/desorption by increasing the synergistic effect of the neighboring pore walls and accordingly slow the adsorption kinetics. To further investigate the hydrogen capacity of 1, the isosteric heat of sorption was calculated from the hydrogen adsorption data collected at 77 and 87 K (Figure a). At the lowest coverage, the Q st reaches 8.1 kJ/mol (Figure S5 of the ). This value is comparable with that of many previous MOFs. Also, the isosteric heat of hydrogen shows little loading dependence, which is in accordance with the fact that the narrow apertures could induce stronger interaction between the gas molecule and the host framework. The selective adsorption of 1 for H2 over N2 at 77 K is comparable with many reported MOFs. This makes it a good candidate for the gas separation processes in H2 enrichment from N2-H2 exhaust mixtures resulting from ammonia synthesis. 

Furthermore, we investigated the material's separation capability between CO2 and CH4, which might be used in the elimination of contaminant carbon dioxide from natural gas and landfill gas streams. Based on the selectivity of H2 over N2, we expected that the selectivity of CO2 over CH4 should be high, owing to the significant differences between gas molecule diameters (CO2 3.30 Å and CH4 3.758 Å) and the molecular sieving effect of the narrow apertures. Indeed, as the experiment reveals, 1 adsorbs 10.6 wt % (54.3 cm3 g-1 STP) CO2 at 273 K and 900 mmHg. However, it could adsorb 1.7 wt % (23.5 cm3 g-1 STP) CH4 under the same condition (Figure b). The permission of CH4 into the cages might be due to the increased gas molecule diffusivity at 273 K. At this temperature, both CO2 and CH4 molecules have sufficient kinetic energy to diffuse within the cages freely. As a result, no hysteresis is observed for both gases. Comparing the adsorption behaviors of 1 at different temperatures, it could be concluded that 1 demonstrates selective adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter at 77 K, which might have application in gas separation purposes.

References

Crystal data for 1: C30H14Co3N4O17, M r = 879.24, trigonal, R3̅m, a = b = 27.422(3) Å, c = 38.087(8) Å, V = 24803(6) Å3, Z = 18, d calcd = 1.060 g⋅cm-3, reflections collected/unique/ observed: 60253/5791/4726, R int = 0.084, final R 1 = 0.0677 (I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.1938 (all data), GOF = 1.08.

porosity.condition: summing voxels more than 1.2 Å away from the framework

selectivity.condition: selective adsorption properties depending on gas molecule diameter

metadata.title: Microporous Metal–Organic Framework Based on Supermolecular Building Blocks (SBBs): Structure Analysis and Selective Gas Adsorption Properties
